member.name: T:Wpf.Services.MicrosoftDI.Configuration.ServiceCollectionExtensions
member.summary:
Extension methods for registering WPF services with Microsoft DI
Usage Notes:
1. Opening Root Windows: - Inject IWindowManager in root ViewModels (e.g., MainViewModel) - Call windowManager.OpenWindow<TViewModel>()
2. Opening Child Windows: - Inject IWindowContext in window ViewModels - Call windowContext.OpenChildWindow<TViewModel>() - Children automatically close when parent closes (scope cascade)
3. Closing Windows: - To close this window: windowContext.CloseWindow() - To close children: windowContext.CloseAllChildWindows() - To close specific window: windowManager.CloseWindow(token)
4. Session Management: - Use IScopeManager.CreateSession(ScopeTag) to create sessions - Sessions manage their own DI scopes
5. Scope Hierarchy: Root Container ├─ IWindowManager (Singleton) ├─ IScopeManager (Singleton) └─ Window Scope (per window) ├─ IWindowContext (scoped - identifies THIS window) ├─ IContentManager (scoped) └─ ViewModels

member.name: T:Wpf.Services.MicrosoftDI.Implementation.ContentManager
member.summary:
Lightweight Content Manager using Microsoft DI - only creation and disposal No tracking, no activation, no caching - just a thin wrapper over DI
Use this when: - You want Navigator to be DI-agnostic - You don't need content tracking/metadata - You manage activation yourself (e.g., in Navigator) - You want minimal overhead
NOTE: Microsoft DI doesn't support TypedParameter like Autofac. Parameters are set via InitializeAsync after construction.
IMPORTANT: Uses IScopedTaggedProvider to ensure tagged services (like IWindowContext) are resolved correctly from the ScopeStore, not created as new instances. IScopedTaggedProvider is automatically available in every tagged scope.
